Air shower (physics).context: Also kaons and baryons may be created
Air shower (physics).sentence: Pions and kaons are not stable, thus they may decay into other particles

Air shower (physics).context:
Detection
The original particle arrives with high energy and hence a velocity near the speed of light, so the products of the collisions tend also to move generally in the same direction as the primary, while to some extent spreading sidewise
Air shower (physics).sentence: In addition, the secondary particles produce a widespread flash of light in forward direction due to the Cherenkov effect, as well as fluorescence light that is emitted isotropically from the excitation of nitrogen molecules

Air shower (physics).context: The telescopes used to measure the fluorescence and Cherenkov light use large mirrors to focus the light on PMT clusters
Air shower (physics).sentence: Finally, air showers emit radio waves due to the deflection of electrons and positrons by the geomagnetic field

Arctic ice pack.context: The regular seasonal cycle there has been an underlying trend of declining sea ice in the Arctic in recent decades as well
Arctic ice pack.sentence:
Climatic importance
Energy balance effects
Sea ice has an important effect on the heat balance of the polar oceans, since it insulates the (relatively) warm ocean from the much colder air above, thus reducing heat loss from the oceans

Arctic ice pack.context: Sea ice is highly reflective of solar radiation, reflecting about 60% of incoming solar radiation when bare and about 80% when covered with snow
Arctic ice pack.sentence: This is due to a feedback known as the albedo effect

Arctic ice pack.context: This is due to a feedback known as the albedo effect
Arctic ice pack.sentence: This is much greater than the reflectivity of the sea (about 10%) and thus the ice also affects the absorption of sunlight at the surface

Arctic ice pack.context:
Odden
In the Arctic, a key area where pancake ice forms the dominant ice type over an entire region is the so-called Odden ice tongue in the Greenland Sea
Arctic ice pack.sentence: The Odden (the word is Norwegian for the headland) grows eastward from the main East Greenland ice edge in the vicinity of 72–74°N during the winter because of the presence of very cold polar surface water in the Jan Mayen Current, which diverts some water eastward from the East Greenland Current at that latitude

Aurora.context: The aurora borealis is visible from being close to the center of the Arctic Circle such as Alaska, Canada, Iceland, Greenland, Norway, Sweden and Finland
Aurora.sentence: A geomagnetic storm causes the auroral ovals (north and south) to expand, bringing the aurora to lower latitudes

Aurora.context:
Forms
According to Clark (2007), there are four main forms that can be seen from the ground, from least to most visible:

A mild glow, near the horizon
Aurora.sentence: These can be close to the limit of visibility, but can be distinguished from moonlit clouds because stars can be seen undiminished through the glow

Aurora.context: A fairly high concentration of atomic oxygen and higher eye sensitivity in green make green auroras the most common
Aurora.sentence: The excited molecular nitrogen (atomic nitrogen being rare due to the high stability of the N2 molecule) plays a role here, as it can transfer energy by collision to an oxygen atom, which then radiates it away at the green wavelength

Aurora.context:
Picket-fence aurora
The processes that cause STEVE also are associated with a picket-fence aurora, although the latter can be seen without STEVE
Aurora.sentence: It is an aurora because it is caused by precipitation of electrons in the atmosphere but it appears outside the auroral oval, closer to the equator than typical auroras

Aurora.context: As a result, the flow of electrons in that region is nearly the same in all directions ("isotropic") and assures a steady supply of leaking electrons
Aurora.sentence: The leakage of electrons does not leave the tail positively charged, because each leaked electron lost to the atmosphere is replaced by a low energy electron drawn upward from the ionosphere

Aurora.context: The complete process, which also generates an electric ring current around Earth, is uncertain
Aurora.sentence: Geomagnetic disturbance from an enhanced solar wind causes distortions of the magnetotail ("magnetic substorms")

Aurora.context: Occasionally the resulting modification of Earth's magnetic field can be so strong that it produces auroras visible at middle latitudes, on field lines much closer to the equator than those of the auroral zone
Aurora.sentence: Acceleration of auroral charged particles invariably accompanies a magnetospheric disturbance that causes an aurora

Aurora.context: Since then an extensive collection of measurements has been acquired painstakingly and with steadily improving resolution since the 1960s by many research teams using rockets and satellites to traverse the auroral zone
Aurora.sentence: The main findings have been that auroral arcs and other bright forms are due to electrons that have been accelerated during the final few 10,000 km or so of their plunge into the atmosphere

Aurora.context: Because the highest parts of the atmosphere contain a higher percentage of oxygen and lower particle densities, such collisions are rare enough to allow time for oxygen to emit red light
Aurora.sentence: Collisions become more frequent progressing down into the atmosphere due to increasing density, so that red emissions do not have time to happen, and eventually, even green light emissions are prevented

Aurora.context: Ionospheric resistance has a complex nature, and leads to a secondary Hall current flow
Aurora.sentence: By a strange twist of physics, the magnetic disturbance on the ground due to the main current almost cancels out, so most of the observed effect of auroras is due to a secondary current, the auroral electrojet

Aurora.context: That alone would tend to line them up in the Sun-Earth direction, but the rotation of the Sun angles them at Earth by about 45 degrees forming a spiral in the ecliptic plane, known as the Parker spiral
Aurora.sentence: The field lines passing Earth are therefore usually linked to those near the western edge ("limb") of the visible Sun at any time

Aurora.context: Some auroral features are also created by electrons accelerated by Alfvén waves
Aurora.sentence: At small wavelengths (comparable to the electron inertial length or ion gyroradius), Alfvén waves develop a significant electric field parallel to the background magnetic field; this can accelerate electrons due to a process of Landau damping

Aurora.context: It is also notable for the fact that it is the first time where the phenomena of auroral activity and electricity were unambiguously linked
Aurora.sentence: This insight was made possible not only due to scientific magnetometer measurements of the era, but also as a result of a significant portion of the 125,000 miles (201,000 km) of telegraph lines then in service being significantly disrupted for many hours throughout the storm

Aurora.context: Walter William Bryant wrote in his book Kepler (1920) that Tycho Brahe "seems to have been something of a homœopathist, for he recommends sulfur to cure infectious diseases 'brought on by the sulphurous vapours of the Aurora Borealis'"
Aurora.sentence:
In 1778, Benjamin Franklin theorized in his paper Aurora Borealis, Suppositions and Conjectures towards forming an Hypothesis for its Explanation that an aurora was caused by a concentration of electrical charge in the polar regions intensified by the snow and moisture in the air: May not then the great quantity of electricity brought into the polar regions by the clouds, which are condens'd there, and fall in snow, which electricity would enter the earth, but cannot penetrate the ice; may it not, I say (as a bottle overcharged) break thro' that low atmosphere and run along in the vacuum over the air towards the equator, diverging as the degrees of longitude enlarge, strongly visible where densest, and becoming less visible as it more diverges; till it finds a passage to the earth in more temperate climates, or is mingled with the upper air?
Observations of the rhythmic movement of compass needles due to the influence of an aurora were confirmed in the Swedish city of Uppsala by Anders Celsius and Olof Hiorter

Aurora.context: In addition, the moons, especially Io, are also powerful sources of aurora
Aurora.sentence: These arise from electric currents along field lines ("field aligned currents"), generated by a dynamo mechanism due to the relative motion between the rotating planet and the moving moon

Belt of Venus.context: As twilight progresses, the arch is separated from the horizon by the dark band of Earth's shadow, or "twilight wedge"
Belt of Venus.sentence: The pinkish glow is due to the Rayleigh scattering of light from the rising or setting Sun, which is then backscattered by particulates

Belt of Venus.context: The name of the phenomenon alludes to the cestus, a girdle or breast-band, of the Ancient Greek goddess Aphrodite, customarily equated with the Roman goddess Venus
Belt of Venus.sentence: Since the greatest elongation (angular separation between the Sun and a Solar System body) of Venus is only 45–48°, the inferior planet never appears in the opposite of the Sun's direction (180° difference in ecliptic longitude) from Earth and is thus never located in the Belt of Venus

Blue hour.context: This shade differs from the colour of the sky on a clear day, which is caused by Rayleigh scattering
Blue hour.sentence: The blue hour occurs when the Sun is far enough below the horizon so that the sunlight's blue wavelengths dominate due to the Chappuis absorption caused by ozone

Blue hour.context:
Explanation and times of occurrence
The still commonly presented incorrect explanation claims that Earth's post-sunset and pre-sunrise atmosphere solely receives and disperses the sun's shorter blue wavelengths and scatters the longer, reddish wavelengths to explain why the hue of this hour is so blue
Blue hour.sentence: In fact, the blue hour occurs when the Sun is far enough below the horizon so that the sunlight's blue wavelengths dominate due to the Chappuis absorption caused by ozone

Blue hour.context: This effect is caused by the relative diffusibility of shorter wavelengths (bluer rays) of visible light versus the longer wavelengths (redder rays)
Blue hour.sentence: During the blue "hour", red light passes through space while blue light is scattered in the atmosphere, and thus reaches Earth's surface

Brine rejection.context: The new water partially freezes within the pores of the ice, increasing the solidity of the ice
Brine rejection.sentence: As sea ice ages and thickens, the initial salinity of the ice decreases due to the rejection of brine over time [Fig

Brine rejection.context:
This occurs in three different ways:

solute diffusion - this depends on the fact that brine inclusions trapped in ice will begin to migrate toward the warmer end of the ice block
Brine rejection.sentence: The ice block is warmest at the water-ice interface, thus pushing the brine out into the water surrounding the ice

Brine rejection.context: The ice block is warmest at the water-ice interface, thus pushing the brine out into the water surrounding the ice
Brine rejection.sentence: gravity drainage - Gravity drainage involves the movement of brine due to differences in density between brine in the interior of the ice and brine in the seawater outside of the ice, which occurs due to the development of a buoyancy driven convection system

Brine rejection.context: gravity drainage - Gravity drainage involves the movement of brine due to differences in density between brine in the interior of the ice and brine in the seawater outside of the ice, which occurs due to the development of a buoyancy driven convection system
Brine rejection.sentence: expulsion - the migration of brine due to cracking produced by thermal expansion of the ice, or pressure caused by the increased volume of the newly formed ice

Brine rejection.context: The annual increase of ice plays a major role in the movement of ocean circulation and deep water formation
Brine rejection.sentence: The density of the water below the newly formed ice increases due to the brine rejection

Brine rejection.context: When surface waters sink, they carry considerable amounts of CO2 into the deep oceans, away from the atmosphere
Brine rejection.sentence: Because these waters are able to contain a large amount of CO2, they have helped slow the rise in atmospheric CO2 concentrations, thus slowing some aspects of climate change

Brine rejection.context: The consequent increase in winter brine rejection will drive ocean ventilation, and strengthen the inflow of warm Atlantic waters
Brine rejection.sentence: Studies of the last glacial maximum (LGM) have indicated that a drastic reduction in the production of sea ice and thus reduction of brine rejection, would result in the weakening of the stratification in the global deep oceans and in CO2 release into the shallow oceans and the atmosphere, triggering global deglaciation

Dawn.context: The simple reading of the Talmud is that dawn takes place 72 minutes before sunrise
Dawn.sentence: Others, including the Vilna Gaon, have the understanding that the Talmud's timeframe for dawn was referring specifically to an equinox day in Mesopotamia, and is therefore teaching that dawn should be calculated daily as commencing when the sun is 16

Double sunset.context: The sun partially reappeared from The Cloud's steep northern slope and soon afterwards set for a second and final time on the horizon
Double sunset.sentence: The spectacle was last reliably witnessed, and filmed, from the churchyard in 1977, but is no longer visible from the location because of tree interference

Double sunset.context: It is, however, still observable from Leek on and around the summer solstice from the road to Pickwood Hall, off Milltown Way, and from Lowe Hill on the outskirts of the town
Double sunset.sentence: Better viewing points, though, are from the A 523, above Rudyard Lake, and Woodhouse Green, both of which are nearer to The Cloud and therefore enable a larger proportion of the sun to reappear

Dusk.context: It marks the end of astronomical twilight, which begins at nautical dusk
Dusk.sentence: After this time the Sun no longer illuminates the sky, and thus no longer interferes with astronomical observations

Eclipse.context: And if both orbits were perfectly circular, then each solar eclipse would be the same type every month
Eclipse.sentence: It is because of the non-planar and non-circular differences that eclipses are not a common event

Eclipse.context: A total eclipse occurs when the observer is within the umbra, an annular eclipse when the observer is within the antumbra, and a partial eclipse when the observer is within the penumbra
Eclipse.sentence: During a lunar eclipse only the umbra and penumbra are applicable, because the antumbra of the Sun-Earth system lies far beyond the Moon

Eclipse.context: During a lunar eclipse only the umbra and penumbra are applicable, because the antumbra of the Sun-Earth system lies far beyond the Moon
Eclipse.sentence: Analogously, Earth's apparent diameter from the viewpoint of the Moon is nearly four times that of the Sun and thus cannot produce an annular eclipse

Eclipse.context: The Moon's umbra will advance eastward at a rate of 1,700 km/h, until it no longer intersects the Earth's surface
Eclipse.sentence: During a solar eclipse, the Moon can sometimes perfectly cover the Sun because its apparent size is nearly the same as the Sun's when viewed from the Earth

Eclipse.context: Sunlight refracted through the Earth's atmosphere enters the umbra and provides a faint illumination
Eclipse.sentence: Much as in a sunset, the atmosphere tends to more strongly scatter light with shorter wavelengths, so the illumination of the Moon by refracted light has a red hue, thus the phrase 'Blood Moon' is often found in descriptions of such lunar events as far back as eclipses are recorded

Eclipse.context: In order to disseminate this information to a broader audience and decrease fear of the consequences of eclipses, booksellers printed broadsides explaining the event either using the science or via astrology
Eclipse.sentence:
Other planets and dwarf planets
Gas giants
The gas giant planets have many moons and thus frequently display eclipses

Eclipse.context: This was used to produce the first estimate of the speed of light
Eclipse.sentence: On the other three gas giants (Saturn, Uranus and Neptune) eclipses only occur at certain periods during the planet's orbit, due to their higher inclination between the orbits of the moon and the orbital plane of the planet

Eclipse.context: By knowing the expected time when an eclipse would be observed at a standard longitude (such as Greenwich), the time difference could be computed by accurately observing the local time of the eclipse
Eclipse.sentence: The time difference gives the longitude of the observer because every hour of difference corresponded to 15° around the Earth's equator

Mars
On Mars, only partial solar eclipses (transits) are possible, because neither of its moons is large enough, at their respective orbital radii, to cover the Sun's disc as seen from the surface of the planet

Equation of time.context: Ignoring very slow changes in the Earth's orbit and rotation, these events are repeated at the same times every tropical year
Equation of time.sentence: However, due to the non-integral number of days in a year, these dates can vary by a day or so from year to year

Equation of time.context: The equation of time is constant only for a planet with zero axial tilt and zero orbital eccentricity
Equation of time.sentence: On Mars the difference between sundial time and clock time can be as much as 50 minutes, due to the considerably greater eccentricity of its orbit

Equation of time.context: From 1767 to 1833, the British Nautical Almanac and Astronomical Ephemeris tabulated the equation of time in the sense 'add or subtract (as directed) the number of minutes and seconds stated to or from the apparent time to obtain the mean time'
Equation of time.sentence: Times in the Almanac were in apparent solar time, because time aboard ship was most often determined by observing the Sun

Equation of time.context: This operation would be performed in the unusual case that the mean solar time of an observation was needed
Equation of time.sentence: In the issues since 1834, all times have been in mean solar time, because by then the time aboard ship was increasingly often determined by marine chronometers

Equation of time.context: Since the equation of time has a range of about 33 minutes, the difference between sundial time and clock time cannot be ignored
Equation of time.sentence: In addition to the equation of time, one also has to apply corrections due to one's distance from the local time zone meridian and summer time, if any

Equation of time.context: In addition to the equation of time, one also has to apply corrections due to one's distance from the local time zone meridian and summer time, if any
Equation of time.sentence: The tiny increase of the mean solar day due to the slowing down of the Earth's rotation, by about 2 ms per day per century, which currently accumulates up to about 1 second every year, is not taken into account in traditional definitions of the equation of time, as it is imperceptible at the accuracy level of sundials

291 km/s, according to Kepler's laws of planetary motion, and its angular speed also varies, and thus the Sun appears to move faster (relative to the background stars) at perihelion (currently around 3 January) and slower at aphelion a half year later

Equation of time.context: In the figure on the right, we can see the monthly variation of the apparent slope of the plane of the ecliptic at solar midday as seen from Earth
Equation of time.sentence: This variation is due to the apparent precession of the rotating Earth through the year, as seen from the Sun at solar midday

Equation of time.context: Positive means: Sun runs fast and culminates earlier, or the sundial is ahead of mean time
Equation of time.sentence: A slight yearly variation occurs due to presence of leap years, resetting itself every 4 years

Equation of time.context: A slight yearly variation occurs due to presence of leap years, resetting itself every 4 years
Equation of time.sentence: The exact shape of the equation of time curve and the associated analemma slowly change over the centuries, due to secular variations in both eccentricity and obliquity

Equation of time.context: The difference, EOT, is measurable since GHA is an angle that can be measured and Universal Time, UT, is a scale for the measurement of time
Equation of time.sentence: The offset by π = 180° = 12 hours from UT is needed because UT is zero at mean midnight while GMHA = 0 at mean noon

Equation of time.context:
Another definition, denoted E to distinguish it from EOT, is

E = GMST − α − UT + offsetHere GMST = GAST − eqeq, is the Greenwich mean sidereal time (the angle between the mean vernal equinox and the mean Sun in the plane of the equator)
Equation of time.sentence: Therefore, GMST is an approximation to GAST (and E is an approximation to EOT); eqeq is called the equation of the equinoxes and is due to the wobbling, or nutation of the Earth's axis of rotation about its precessional motion

Equation of time.context: For the small value of e that characterises the Earth's orbit this gives a very good approximation for ν(M)
Equation of time.sentence:
Next, knowing ν, calculate λ from its definition:

λ = ν + λpThe value of λ varies non-linearly with M because the orbit is elliptical and not circular

Equation of time.context:
From the approximation for ν:

λ ≈ M + λp + 2e sin M + 5/4e2 sin 2M
Equation of time.sentence:
Finally, knowing λ calculate α from a relation for the right triangle on the celestial sphere shown above: 22 
α = tan−1(cos ε tan λ)Note that the quadrant of α is the same as that of λ, therefore reduce λ to the range 0 to 2π and write

α = Tan−1 (cos ε tan λ) + kπ,where k is 0 if λ is in quadrant 1, it is 1 if λ is in quadrants 2 or 3 and it is 2 if λ is in quadrant 4

Equation of time.context:
Equation of time
The equation of time is obtained by substituting the result of the right ascension calculation into an equation of time formula
Equation of time.sentence: Here Δt(M) = M + λp − α[λ(M)] is used; in part because small corrections (of the order of 1 second), that would justify using E, are not included, and in part because the goal is to obtain a simple analytical expression

Equation of time.context: Here Δt(M) = M + λp − α[λ(M)] is used; in part because small corrections (of the order of 1 second), that would justify using E, are not included, and in part because the goal is to obtain a simple analytical expression
Equation of time.sentence: Using two-term approximations for λ(M) and α(λ) allows Δt to be written as an explicit expression of two terms, which is designated Δtey because it is a first order approximation in e and in y

Equation of time.context: 938201 radians that correspond to the epoch 1 January 2000 at 12 noon UT1
Equation of time.sentence: When evaluating the numerical expression for Δtey as given above, a calculator must be in radian mode to obtain correct values because the value of 2λp − 2π in the argument of the second term is written there in radians

Equation of time.context: This puts the periapsis on 4 January 2000 at 00:11:41 while the actual periapsis is, according to results from the Multiyear Interactive Computer Almanac (abbreviated as MICA), on 3 January 2000 at 05:17:30
Equation of time.sentence: This large discrepancy happens because the difference between the orbital radius at the two locations is only 1 part in a million; in other words, radius is a very weak function of time near periapsis

Equation of time.context: In this event it is no more difficult to evaluate Δt using a computer than any of its approximations
Equation of time.sentence: In all this note that Δtey as written above is easy to evaluate, even with a calculator, is accurate enough (better than 1 minute over the 80-year range) for correcting sundials, and has the nice physical explanation as the sum of two terms, one due to obliquity and the other to eccentricity that was used previously in the article

Espresso crema effect.context: Besides the physical changes, chemical differences compared to the bulk medium may be involved
Espresso crema effect.sentence: Because of increased gas–solid interfaces which result, for example due to selective leaching processes during burial, surfaces of ancient ceramics can appear brighter than they originally were

Fog bow.context: 0020 in)—the fog bow has only very weak colors, with a red outer edge and bluish inner edge
Fog bow.sentence: In many cases, when the droplets are very small, fog bows appear white, and are therefore sometimes called white rainbows

Fog bow.context: Mariners sometimes call fog bows sea-dogs
Fog bow.sentence:
Direction
A fog bow is seen in the same direction as a rainbow, thus the sun would be behind the head of the observer and the direction of view would be into a bank of fog (which may not be noticeable in directions away from the bow itself)

Frazil ice.context: The supercooled water will already be encouraging the formation of small ice crystals (frazil ice) and the crystals get taken to the bottom of the water body
Frazil ice.sentence: Ice generally floats, but due to frazil ice's small size relative to current speeds, it has an ineffective buoyancy and can be carried to the bottom very easily

Frazil ice.context: Ice generally floats, but due to frazil ice's small size relative to current speeds, it has an ineffective buoyancy and can be carried to the bottom very easily
Frazil ice.sentence: Through a process called secondary nucleation, the crystals quickly increase in number, and because of its supercooled surrounding, the crystals will continue to grow

Frazil ice.context: As the crystals grow in number and size, the frazil ice will begin to adhere to objects in the water, especially if the objects themselves are at a temperature below water's freezing point
Frazil ice.sentence: The accumulation of frazil ice often causes flooding or damage to objects such as trash racks

Frazil ice.context: The growth will extend upstream and increase in width until the point where the frazil ice accumulations bridge together and block the water
Frazil ice.sentence: As more and more water flows against this block, the pressure on the upstream side increases and causes a differential pressure (difference in pressure from the upstream side and the downstream side)

Frazil ice.context: Once this happens, flooding and damage is likely unless otherwise prevented
Frazil ice.sentence: Frazil ice has also been demonstrated to form beneath temperate (or "warm-based") glaciers as water flows quickly downhill and supercools due to a rapid loss of pressure

Frazil ice.context: Subsequent freezing and recrystallization can result in a layer of sediment-rich ice at the base of the glacier which, upon melting at the terminus, can result in significant accumulation of sediment in moraines
Frazil ice.sentence: This phenomenon has been verified by elevated concentrations of tritium — produced by nuclear weapons testing and therefore almost entirely absent in ice frozen before 1945 — in the basal ice of several glaciers (signifying young ice) and the observation of rapid growth of ice crystals around water discharge vents at glacier termini

Frazil ice.context: They include suppression, mechanical control, thermal control, vibration, materials selection and damage mitigation
Frazil ice.sentence:
Suppression
Frazil ice forms in supercooled water which occurs because the surface water loses heat to cooler air above

Frazil ice.context:
Mechanical control
These methods include stabilizing freeze without restricting water flow, such as implementing weirs and ice booms, installing water jets to break up any accumulation that might occur, and using manual labour to rake away the accumulation
Frazil ice.sentence: This final method is often not preferred because of high labour costs, cold, wet and late night working conditions

Earthlight (astronomy).context: This phenomenon is most visible from Earth at night (or astronomical twilight) a few days before or after the day of new moon, when the lunar phase is a thin crescent
Earthlight (astronomy).sentence: On these nights, the entire lunar disk is both directly and indirectly sunlit, and is thus unevenly bright enough to see

Measurement of sea ice.context: Sea ice may be considered in terms of total volume, or in terms of areal coverage
Measurement of sea ice.sentence: Volume is harder, because it requires a knowledge of the ice thickness, which is hard to measure directly; efforts such as PIOMAS use a combination of observations and modelling to estimate total volume

Measurement of sea ice.context: Its active service period was from February 2003 to October 2009
Measurement of sea ice.sentence: Together with a set of auxiliary data like ice density, snow cover thickness, air pressure, water salinity one can calculate the flow thickness and thus its volume

Measurement of sea ice.context: The magnitude of the ice changes associated with the AAO and ENSO are smaller than the regional ice trends and local (or less understood large) scale processes still need to be investigated for a complete explanations
Measurement of sea ice.sentence:
Use of 1981 to 2010 as a baseline
Scientists use the 1981 to 2010 average because it provides a consistent baseline for year-to-year comparisons of sea ice extent

Melt pond.context: Melt ponds can melt through to the ocean's surface
Melt pond.sentence: Seawater entering the pond increases the melt rate because the salty water of the ocean is warmer than the fresh water of the pond

Midnight sun.context: When the midnight sun is seen in the Arctic, the Sun appears to move from left to right, but in Antarctica the equivalent apparent motion is from right to left
Midnight sun.sentence: This occurs at latitudes from 65°44' to 90° north or south, and does not stop exactly at the Arctic Circle or the Antarctic Circle, due to refraction

Midnight sun.context: During the six months that the Sun is above the horizon, it spends the days continuously moving in circles around the observer, gradually spiralling higher and reaching its highest circuit of the sky at the summer solstice
Midnight sun.sentence: Because of atmospheric refraction, and also because the Sun is a disc rather than a point, the midnight sun may be experienced at latitudes slightly south of the Arctic Circle or north of the Antarctic Circle, though not exceeding one degree (depending on local conditions)
This is because Fairbanks is 51 minutes ahead of its idealized time zone (as most of the state is in one time zone) and Alaska observes daylight saving time

Midnight sun.context: 5 degrees above its own axis in its orbit
Midnight sun.sentence: This causes the part of Norway located in the Arctic region at the North Pole of Earth to move very close to the Sun and during this time the length of the day increases

Plasma fountain.context: This paradox consists of the fact that helium in the Earth's atmosphere seems to be produced (via radioactive decay of uranium and thorium) faster than it is lost by escaping from the upper atmosphere
Plasma fountain.sentence: The realization that some helium could be ionized, and therefore escape the earth along open magnetic field lines near the magnetic poles (the 'polar wind'), is one possible solution to the paradox

Polar night.context: For regions inside the polar circles, the maximum lengths of the time that the Sun is completely below the horizon varies from zero to a few days beyond the Arctic Circle and Antarctic Circle to 179 days at the Poles
Polar night.sentence: However, not all this time is classified as polar night since sunlight may be visible because of refraction

Polar night.context: This means that the Sun is below the horizon, but by less than 6°
Polar night.sentence: During civil twilight, there may still be enough light for most normal outdoor activities because of light scattering by the upper atmosphere and refraction

Polar night.context: Nautical twilight happens when the Sun is between six and twelve degrees below the horizon
Polar night.sentence: There is a location at the horizon around midday with more light than others because of refraction

Polynya.sentence: Latent heat polynyas are therefore a major source of sea ice production in the Antarctic

Polynya.context: Latent heat polynyas are therefore a major source of sea ice production in the Antarctic
Polynya.sentence: Latent heat polynyas are regions of high ice production and therefore are possible sites of dense water production in both polar regions

Polynya.context: Polar bears are known to be able to swim as far as 65 kilometres (40 mi) across open waters of a polynya
Polynya.sentence: The presence of polynyas in McMurdo Sound in the Antarctic provides an ice-free area where penguins can feed, and therefore they are important for the survival of the Cape Royds penguin colony

Reverse waterfall.sentence: Reverse waterfall is a phenomenon in which water is blown upward due to strong wind in waterfalls giving an apparent perception of water flowing upwards

Reverse waterfall.context:
India:
A waterfall at Naneghat in Malshej Ghat Road near Mumbai
Samrad village in the Sandhan Valley has waterfalls showing reverse waterfall during monsoon
Reverse waterfall.sentence: Amboli hills near Belgaum have various waterfalls that becomes active in monsoon which gets blown upward due to strong wind

Reverse waterfall.context: Amboli hills near Belgaum have various waterfalls that becomes active in monsoon which gets blown upward due to strong wind
Reverse waterfall.sentence: Hawaii: The Waipuhia Falls in Oahu gets reversed due to north-easterly trade winds

Sea ice.context: In contrast, a weathered ridge is one with a rounded crest and with sides sloping at less than 40 degrees
Sea ice.sentence: Stamukhi are yet another type of pile-up but these are grounded and are therefore relatively stationary

Sea ice.context: They result from the interaction between fast ice and the drifting pack ice
Sea ice.sentence: Level ice is sea ice that has not been affected by deformation, and is therefore relatively flat

Sea ice.context: The growth and melt rate are also affected by the state of the ice itself
Sea ice.sentence: During growth, the ice thickening due to freezing (as opposed to dynamics) is itself dependent on the thickness, so that the ice growth slows as the ice thickens

Sea ice.context: the presence of natural basins for the melt ponds to form in
Sea ice.sentence: First year ice is flatter than multiyear ice due to the lack of dynamic ridging, so ponds tend to have greater area

Sea ice.context: Antarctic sea ice extent gradually increased in the period of satellite observations, which began in 1979, until a rapid decline in southern hemisphere spring of 2016
Sea ice.sentence:
Relationship to global warming and climate change
Sea ice provides an ecosystem for various polar species, particularly the polar bear, whose environment is being threatened as global warming causes the ice to melt more as the Earth's temperature gets warmer

Sea ice.context: The bright, shiny surface (albedo) of the ice also serves a role in maintaining cooler polar temperatures by reflecting much of the sunlight that hits it back into space
Sea ice.sentence: As the sea ice melts, its surface area shrinks, diminishing the size of the reflective surface and therefore causing the earth to absorb more of the sun's heat

Sea ice.context: As the sea ice melts, its surface area shrinks, diminishing the size of the reflective surface and therefore causing the earth to absorb more of the sun's heat
Sea ice.sentence: As the ice melts it lowers the albedo thus causing more heat to be absorbed by the Earth and further increase the amount of melting ice

Sea ice.context: As the ice melts it lowers the albedo thus causing more heat to be absorbed by the Earth and further increase the amount of melting ice
Sea ice.sentence: Though the size of the ice floes is affected by the seasons, even a small change in global temperature can greatly affect the amount of sea ice, and due to the shrinking reflective surface that keeps the ocean cool, this sparks a cycle of ice shrinking and temperatures warming

Sky brightness.context: How sodium gets to mesospheric heights is not yet well understood, but it is believed to be a combination of upward transport of sea salt and meteoritic dust
Sky brightness.sentence: In daytime, sodium and red oxygen emissions are dominant and roughly 1,000 times as bright as nighttime emissions because in daytime, the upper atmosphere is fully exposed to solar UV radiation

Sky brightness.context: 7 nm oxygen line is dominant, and atmospheric scattering of starlight occurs
Sky brightness.sentence: Differential refraction causes different parts of the spectrum to dominate, producing a golden hour and a blue hour

)
The total sky brightness in zenith is therefore ~220 S10 or 21

Sort sol.context: Sort sol in the marsh near Tønder can occasionally comprise a formation with up to one million birds
Sort sol.sentence: Usually flocks break up when the number of individuals exceed about half a million birds due to excessive internal disturbances in the flock

Sort sol.context: In rare cases the sticky deposits may render the predator unable to stay airborne
Sort sol.sentence: Over 20 years, there have been two confirmed cases of young northern goshawks who drowned because the incident took place over water

Steve (atmospheric phenomenon).context: However, the first accurate determination of what STEVE is was not made until after members of a Facebook group called Alberta Aurora Chasers named it, attributed it to a proton aurora, and called it a "proton arc"
Steve (atmospheric phenomenon).sentence: When physics professor Eric Donovan from the University of Calgary saw their photographs, he suspected that was not the case because proton auroras are not visible

Sunrise.context: The term can also refer to the entire process of the solar disk crossing the horizon and its accompanying atmospheric effects
Sunrise.sentence:
Terminology
"Rise"
Although the Sun appears to "rise" from the horizon, it is actually the Earth's motion that causes the Sun to appear

Sunrise.context: The period after the Sun rises during which striking colors and atmospheric effects are still seen
Sunrise.sentence:
Measurement
Angle
The stage of sunrise known as false sunrise actually occurs before the Sun truly reaches the horizon because Earth's atmosphere refracts the Sun's image

Sunrise.context: Variations in atmospheric refraction can alter the time of sunrise by changing its apparent position
Sunrise.sentence: Near the poles, the time-of-day variation is exaggerated, since the Sun crosses the horizon at a very shallow angle and thus rises more slowly

Sunrise.context: The remaining reddened sunlight can then be scattered by cloud droplets and other relatively large particles to light up the horizon red and orange
Sunrise.sentence: The removal of the shorter wavelengths of light is due to Rayleigh scattering by air molecules and particles much smaller than the wavelength of visible light (less than 50 nm in diameter)

Sunrise.context: The removal of the shorter wavelengths of light is due to Rayleigh scattering by air molecules and particles much smaller than the wavelength of visible light (less than 50 nm in diameter)
Sunrise.sentence: The scattering by cloud droplets and other particles with diameters comparable to or larger than the sunlight's wavelengths (more than 600 nm) is due to Mie scattering and is not strongly wavelength-dependent

Sunrise.context: Mie scattering is responsible for the light scattered by clouds, and also for the daytime halo of white light around the Sun (forward scattering of white light)
Sunrise.sentence: Sunset colors are typically more brilliant than sunrise colors, because the evening air contains more particles than morning air

Sunrise.context: The high altitude clouds serve to reflect strongly reddened sunlight still striking the stratosphere after sunset, down to the surface
Sunrise.sentence:
Optical illusions and other phenomena
Atmospheric refraction causes the Sun to be seen while it is still below the horizon

Sunset.sentence: Sunset, also known as sundown, is the daily disappearance of the Sun below the horizon due to Earth's rotation

Sunset.context: The time of sunset is defined in astronomy as the moment when the upper limb of the Sun disappears below the horizon
Sunset.sentence: Near the horizon, atmospheric refraction causes sunlight rays to be distorted to such an extent that geometrically the solar disk is already about one diameter below the horizon when a sunset is observed

Sunset.context: As sunrise and sunset are calculated from the leading and trailing edges of the Sun, respectively, and not the center, the duration of a daytime is slightly longer than nighttime (by about 10 minutes, as seen from temperate latitudes)
Sunset.sentence: Further, because the light from the Sun is refracted as it passes through the Earth's atmosphere, the Sun is still visible after it is geometrically below the horizon

Sunset.context: The remaining reddened sunlight can then be scattered by cloud droplets and other relatively large particles to light up the horizon red and orange
Sunset.sentence: The removal of the shorter wavelengths of light is due to Rayleigh scattering by air molecules and particles much smaller than the wavelength of visible light (less than 50 nm in diameter)

Sunset.context: The removal of the shorter wavelengths of light is due to Rayleigh scattering by air molecules and particles much smaller than the wavelength of visible light (less than 50 nm in diameter)
Sunset.sentence: The scattering by cloud droplets and other particles with diameters comparable to or larger than the sunlight's wavelengths (> 600 nm) is due to Mie scattering and is not strongly wavelength-dependent

Sunset.context: Mie scattering is responsible for the light scattered by clouds, and also for the daytime halo of white light around the Sun (forward scattering of white light)
Sunset.sentence: Sunset colors are typically more brilliant than sunrise colors, because the evening air contains more particles than morning air

Sunset.context: to French "(se) lever" meaning "lift" or "rise" (and also to English "elevate"), is also used to describe the east
Sunset.sentence: In Polish, the word for east wschód (vskhud), is derived from the morpheme "ws" – meaning "up", and "chód" – signifying "move" (from the verb chodzić – meaning "walk, move"), due to the act of the Sun coming up from behind the horizon

Sunset.context: The Polish word for west, zachód (zakhud), is similar but with the word "za" at the start, meaning "behind", from the act of the Sun going behind the horizon
Sunset.sentence: In Russian, the word for west, запад (zapad), is derived from the words за – meaning "behind", and пад – signifying "fall" (from the verb падать – padat'), due to the act of the Sun falling behind the horizon

Sunset.context:
Historical view
The 16th-century astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus was the first to present to the world a detailed and eventually widely accepted mathematical model supporting the premise that the Earth is moving and the Sun actually stays still, despite the impression from our point of view of a moving Sun
Sunset.sentence:
Planets
Sunsets on other planets appear different because of differences in the distance of the planet from the Sun and non-existent or differing atmospheric compositions

Sunset.context:
Planets
Sunsets on other planets appear different because of differences in the distance of the planet from the Sun and non-existent or differing atmospheric compositions
Sunset.sentence:
Mars
On Mars, the setting Sun appears about two-thirds the size as it appears from Earth, due to the greater distance between Mars and the Sun

Surface runoff.context: This can occur when the soil is saturated by water to its full capacity, and that the rain arrives more quickly than the soil can absorb it
Surface runoff.sentence: Surface runoff often occurs because impervious areas (such as roofs and pavement) do not allow water to soak into the ground

Surface runoff.context: In areas where there is no snow, runoff will come from rainfall
Surface runoff.sentence: However, not all rainfall will produce runoff because storage from soils can absorb light showers
This more commonly occurs in arid and semi-arid regions, where rainfall intensities are high and the soil infiltration capacity is reduced because of surface sealing, or in paved areas

Surface runoff.context: It is instead forced directly into streams or storm water runoff drains, where erosion and siltation can be major problems, even when flooding is not
Surface runoff.sentence: Increased runoff reduces groundwater recharge, thus lowering the water table and making droughts worse, especially for agricultural farmers and others who depend on the water wells

Surface runoff.context: Sheet erosion is the overland transport of sediment by runoff without a well defined channel
Surface runoff.sentence: Soil surface roughness causes may cause runoff to become concentrated into narrower flow paths: as these incise, the small but well-defined channels which are formed are known as rills

Surface runoff.context: Shifting cultivation is a farming system which sometimes incorporates the slash and burn method in some regions of the world
Surface runoff.sentence: Erosion causes loss of the fertile top soil and reduces its fertility and quality of the agricultural produce

Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) in 1976, and later the Water Quality Act of 1987, states and cities have become more vigilant in controlling the containment and storage of toxic chemicals, thus preventing releases and leakage

Surface runoff.context: This computer model formed the basis of much of the mitigation study that led to strategies for land use and chemical handling controls
Surface runoff.sentence: Increasingly, stormwater practitioners have recognized the need for Monte Carlo models to simulate stormwater processes because of natural variations in multiple variables that affect the quality and quantity of runofff

Surface runoff.context: SELDM is designed to transform complex scientific data into meaningful information about the risk of adverse effects of runoff on receiving waters, the potential need for mitigation measures, and the potential effectiveness of such management measures for reducing these risks
Surface runoff.sentence: SELDM provides a method for rapid assessment of information that is otherwise difficult or impossible to obtain because it models the interactions among hydrologic variables (with different probability distributions) that result in a population of values that represent likely long-term outcomes from runoff processes and the potential effects of different mitigation measures

Terminator (solar).context: The terminator is defined as the locus of points on a planet or moon where the line through the center of its parent star is tangent
Terminator (solar).sentence: An observer on the terminator of such an orbiting body with an atmosphere would experience twilight due to light scattering by particles in the gaseous layer

Terminator (solar).context: The circle separates the portion of Earth experiencing daylight from that experiencing darkness (night)
Terminator (solar).sentence: While a little over one half of Earth is illuminated at any point in time (with exceptions during eclipses), the terminator path varies by time of day due to Earth's rotation on its axis

Terminator (solar).context: While a little over one half of Earth is illuminated at any point in time (with exceptions during eclipses), the terminator path varies by time of day due to Earth's rotation on its axis
Terminator (solar).sentence: The terminator path also varies by time of year due to Earth's orbital revolution around the Sun; thus, the plane of the terminator is nearly parallel to planes created by lines of longitude during the equinoxes, and its maximum angle is approximately 23

Terminator (solar).context:
Grey-line radio propagation
Strength of radio propagation changes between day- and night-side of the ionosphere
Terminator (solar).sentence: This is primarily because the D layer, which absorbs high frequency signals, disappears rapidly on the dark side of the terminator, whereas the E and F layers above the D layer take longer to form

Terminator (solar).context: a line perpendicular to the terminator) should correspond with the position of the Sun, but does not appear to do so
Terminator (solar).sentence: The cause of the illusion is simply the observer not taking into account that the observed slope of a light ray will change across the sky because of the lack of visual clues to establish 3D perspective

Terminator (solar).context: Images showing a planetary terminator can be used to map topography: the position of the tip of a mountain behind the terminator line is measured when the Sun still or already illuminates it while the base of the mountain remains in shadow
Terminator (solar).sentence: Low Earth orbit satellites take advantage of the fact that certain polar orbits set near the terminator do not suffer from eclipse, therefore their solar cells are continuously lit by sunlight

Twilight.sentence: Twilight is the illumination of the lower atmosphere when the Sun is not directly visible because it is below the horizon

Twilight.context: At civil dawn and at civil dusk sunlight clearly defines the horizon while the brightest stars and planets can appear
Twilight.sentence: As observed from the Earth (see apparent magnitude), sky-gazers know Venus, the brightest planet, as the "morning star" or "evening star" because they can see it during civil twilight

Twilight.context: This also occurs for most observers at higher latitudes on many dates throughout the year, except those around the summer solstice
Twilight.sentence: However, at latitudes closer than 9 degrees (between 81° and 90°) to either Pole, the Sun cannot rise above the horizon nor sink more than 18 degrees below it on the same day on any date, this example of twilight cannot occur because the angular difference between solar noon and solar midnight elevates less than 18 degrees

Twilight.context: At the equator, civil twilight can last as little as 24 minutes
Twilight.sentence: This is true because at low latitudes the sun's apparent movement is perpendicular to the observer's horizon

Twilight.context: Astronomical twilight from nautical dusk to nautical dawn: Hulun Buir, Erdenet, Nur-Sultan, Samara, Kyiv, Minsk, Alytus, Warsaw, Košice, Paris, Dublin, Zwettl, Prague, Stanley (Falkland Islands), Berlin, Hamburg, Luxembourg City, Brussels, Amsterdam, London, Cardiff, Vancouver, Calgary, Unalaska, Bellingham (largest in the continental USA), Rio Gallegos, and Punta Arenas
Twilight.sentence: Major cities that near astronomical twilight from nautical dusk to nautical dawn: Khabarovsk (48°29'0"N), Dnipro (48°27'0"N), Victoria (48°25'42"N), Saguenay (48°25′0"N), Brest (48°23′26"N), Thunder Bay (48°22′56″N), Vienna (48°12′30″N), Bratislava (48°8′38″N), Munich (48°8'0"N)Although Helsinki, Oslo, Stockholm, Tallinn, and Saint Petersburg also enter into nautical twilight after sunset, they do have noticeably lighter skies at night during the summer solstice than other locations mentioned in their category above, because they do not go far into nautical twilight
